course.subject: CENG
course.name: Introduction to Food Science and Technology
course.description: This experiential learning course consists of lectures, experiments and design project. Lectures introduce food chemistry, nutrition, processing, additives, safety, regulations, genetically modified foods and healthy foods etc. Experiments and design project encourage students to learn by doing, helping them obtain hands-on experiences and develop problem solving skills.

reviews.author: churbao
reviews.title: Best Course
reviews.comment_content:
The course is mainly about DSE knowledge, mostly Biology and Chemistry. But its basic common sense, easy to follow.

1 Introduction
2 Food Chemistry
3 Changes in processing
4 Nutrition
5 Processing at Ambient Temp (Separ Conc Ferm)
6 Processing with heat or heat removal
7 Food Additive and Safety
8 New food & technique.pdf
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Liu is very inclusive and requires everyone to attend the lecture as much as possible and willing to learn everyone's name!  The lecture is so fun to attend, once Professor brings experiment to the classroom, we can learn how to make Bread and ice cream with liquid Nitrogen.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 Assignment
1 Group Project
1 Group Lab report
1 Individual Lab report
4 Quizzes ( 3 is MC and 1 is MC + short question )

Assignment marked by professor only give highest 9.
( mean : around 8 )

Quiz x 4 : higher than mean

Group Lab report : 8 / 10 ( mean: 8 )
Individual lab report: 8.5 / 10 ( mean : 7.86 )

Group Project:
submitted in video but need to attend in person Q&A session and answer questions raised by students
Mark: unknown ( requires professor and peer marking )

At last I got A+, unexpected but I think group project values the most and professor's impression is important. He tends to give a higher mark.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is huge I think. Theres Lab each week
Lab 1: Bread and Cookies
Lab 2: Tofu
Lab 3: Bubble
Lab 4: Beer

Plant Visit x 1
Assignment and Quiz each week

The workload is huge but the professor is flexible. only 3 credit this summer seems okay to me. But do expect to give professor more questions and answer the discussion in class to get more participation mark ( even its not included in the syllabus )

reviews.author: yching
reviews.title: An interesting course and good professor
reviews.comment_content:
1Lect: Course introduction
2Lect: Scientific principles (chemistry, deterioration) and Sensory evaluation
3Lect: Nutrition
4Lect: Food processing (Separation, Fermentation, Blanching, Pasteurization, Sterilization, Drying)
5Lect: Food Preservation (Chilling, Freezing) and packaging
6Lect: Food safety, additives, law and regulation
7Lect: Functional food, Food waste management, future food, advanced processing technologies
8Presentation and Course wrap-up

4labs in total
Topic: Cookies&Bread, Tofu, Popping bubbles, Beer

1-2 Plants visit (during the last week lab session)
Yakult, Lee Kum Kee, craft beer
reviews.comment_teaching: Marshal is a really fun and passionate professor. He will give a lot of extra information and personal experience. Sometimes he will make or bring some food to the lesson. He will also try to remember the name of all the students and he will come and chat with you during break time. And really friendly and interesting professor :) Must attend his f2f lesson
reviews.comment_grading:
1.Class participation and performance 10%
2.Quizzes (open books and computer) 30%
3. Lab performance and reports 30%
4. Assignments (including plant visit report) 15%
5. Group project(Video or recorded presentation)15%

He always gives high marks. The lowest mark of most of the assignments is 7 out of 10. The mean is about 8-8.5.

Personally, all assignments are above mean and some quiz and lab reports are below mean.
Final grade: A-
(He said most of them will get B or above and a lots will get A range)
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy.
You need to do 1 group report (10 pages)
1 individual report (5 pages)
4 open book quizzes in class
4 assignment
1 group project (video recording)
And you group must have students from different major

reviews.author: SATB
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction
2. Food Chemistry
3. Food Changes
4. Nutrition
5. Processing at Ambient Temperature
6. Processing by Heating or Heat Removal
7. Food Additives, Safety, and Regulation
8. New Products & Technologies

The contents sure are interesting to learn, but they may not be useful to everyone in the future.

There were also 4 experiments, including making bread & cookies, tofu, popping boba, and beer. You'll have to write 2 reports on 2 experiments, one group report and one individual report.

There was also a plant visit (1 out of 3, yakult, lee kum kee, and a beer brewery)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Marshal is very patient, he is willing to answer all questions you ask in detail. You may ask him questions during or after the lectures, in person, or by email. He also responds to emails rapidly.

He has a special accent though, it may be a bit difficult to understand at the beginning.

He tried to make the class as interactive as possible.
reviews.comment_grading:
1) Class participation and performance 10%
2) Quizzes (open books and computer) 30%
3) Lab performance and reports 30%
4) Assignments (including plant visit report) 15%
5) Group project (Video or recorded presentation) 15%

He said everyone in the class can get B or above.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite high.
There were 4 pieces of assignment, 4 quizzes (3 MCs, 1 MC + LQ), 2 lab reports (1 group + 1 individual), and 1 group project. Consider that the summer semester is only 1.5 months long, everything is kind of crammed together. If you want to take this course, make sure you can arrange your time well, the best case is you have nothing else to do for the summer.

Marshal also allows students to skip lessons and watch lecture videos but lab counts attendance.

reviews.title: 【I don’t have time to finish writing it now, modify later】
reviews.comment_content:
• This course aims to provide students with fundamental knowledge of
food science (chemistry, nutrition, microbiology, etc.), safety issues
and technologies for daily consumption, and preliminary perspective
for further exploration on food processing technologies.
• Experiential learning will be adopted for more practicum/team-
based opportunities to broaden students’ professional interests and
exposure, and to help students across different disciplines to learn in
real life contexts for stimulating their creativity.
• Critical thinking is reinforced when students are exposed to daily
rumors or controversies about food. Students will be guided to know
the secrets behind food production.
